definition: to refute
to curve/to return/to revolve
to circle/to go back/to turn around/to answer/to return/to revolve/Hui ethnic group (Chinese Muslims)/time/classifier for acts of a play/section or chapter (of a classic book)
variant of 迴|回[hui2]
variant of 駁|驳[bo2]
variegated/heterogeneous/to refute/to contradict/to ship by barge/a barge/a lighter (ship)

sentences.english: I retorted, roused to something like passion.
sentences.chinese: 我回驳着，感情很有些冲动。

definition: to retort/to refute
to ask (a question) in reply/to answer a question with a question/rhetorical question
to dispute/to refute
to refute/to debunk/to deny/to denounce
to rebuke/to reprimand
to twist words and force logic (idiom)/sophistry/loud rhetoric making up for fallacious argument/shoving false arguments down people's throats
to offer an explanation/to plead innocence/to try to defend oneself
to answer back sarcastically (idiom)/to retort
to argue strenuously or with sophistry/to quibble
to retort/to answer back
dumbstruck and unable to reply (idiom); left speechless/at a loss for words
to speak forcefully and with justice (idiom); to argue with the courage of one's convictions/also written 振振有詞|振振有词
to speak forcibly out of a sense of righteousness (idiom)
faulty argument and poor rhetoric (idiom); unable to put forward any convincing arguments/without a leg to stand on
to speak forcefully and with justice (idiom); to argue with the courage of one's convictions
to upbraid
